facts.text: Two appeals filed by Municipal Committee, Raipur against two different respondents who carry on business of extraction of oil from oil seeds.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-These two appeals by special leave have been filed by the Municipal Committee, Raipur, against two different respondents who carry on business of extraction of oil from oil seeds.

facts.text: Respondents brought sarso oil seeds within the area of Municipal Committee, Raipur for purposes of their business.

anchor.surface_text: The case involves an interpretation of the Byelaws of the Municipal Committee and the determination of octroi duty which was payable by the respondents in the relevant years of assessment on sarso oil seeds brought by them within the area of the appellant Committee for purposes of their business.

facts.text: Municipal Committee demanded ad valorem octroi duty of Rs. 4-11-0 per cent under item 44 of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Committee demanded an ad valorem octroi duty Rs. 4-11-0 per cent from the respondents, claiming to levy it under item 44 of the Schedule of goods liable to octroi duty in the Raipur Municipality, appended to the Rules framed on June 4, 1951.

facts.text: Respondents contended that duty of 2 annas per maund was leviable under item 4 of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, on the other hand companytended that a duty of 2 annas per maund was leviable under item 4 of the same Schedule, which companyered the case of oil seeds.

facts.text: Respondents made representations described as appeals, but were unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents made representations described as appeals, but were unsuccessful. Their demand for refund of octroi duty paid by them was refused

facts.text: Demand for refund of octroi duty paid by respondents was refused.

anchor.surface_text: Their demand for refund of octroi duty paid by them was refused and they, therefore, filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Nagpur  later, of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Respondents filed petitions under Art. 226 in High Court of Nagpur later Madhya Pradesh against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: and they, therefore, filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Nagpur  later, of Madhya Pradesh  against the appellants alleging inter alia that this imposition of octroi duty ad valorem at Rs. 4-11-0 percent on sarso oil seeds as against other oil seeds was ultra vires the Municipal Committee under Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondents alleged imposition of ad valorem duty on sarso oil seeds ultra vires under Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: against the appellants alleging inter alia that this imposition of octroi duty ad valorem at Rs. 4-11-0 percent on sarso oil seeds as against other oil seeds was ultra vires the Municipal Committee under Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Learned single Judge held sarso oil seeds chargeable under item 44.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, the petition out of which Civil Appeal No. 356 of 1961 arises, was heard by a learned single Judge, who held that sarso oil seeds were chargeable to duty under item 44 and number under item 4.

facts.text: Constitutional question not urged before single Judge.

anchor.surface_text: From the order of the learned single Judge, it does appear that the companystitutional question was urged before him.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal filed against single Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order, a Letters Patent Appeal was filed, and the Divisional Bench, which heard the appeal,

facts.text: Divisional Bench held duty leviable only under item 4.

anchor.surface_text: held, disagreeing with the learned single Judge, that duty was properly leviable only under item 4.

facts.text: Constitutional question not argued before Divisional Bench in LPA.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Divisional Bench also, it does number appear that the companystitutional question was argued.

facts.text: Misc Petition No. 254 of 1959 heard by Divisional Bench which followed earlier decision against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, out of which Civil Appeal No. 357 of 1961 arises was heard by a Divisional Bench, which, following the earlier decision, decided against the appellant Committee.

facts.text: Schedule has eight classes of goods, 67 items.

anchor.surface_text: The entries in the Schedule of goods liable to octroi duty in the Raipur Municipality companytain eight classes of goods. Under them are grouped 67 items,

facts.text: Item 4 in Class I: Oil-seeds of every description number specifically mentioned elsewhere, duty 2 annas per maund.

anchor.surface_text: Class I is headed Articles of food or drink or use for men or animals. Item 4, which is in that Class reads Oil-seeds of every description number specifically mentioned elsewhere. ... Item 4 is chargeable to a duty of 2 annas per maund,

facts.text: Item 44 in Class V: Betel-nuts, gums, spices... sarso, etc. known as kirana groceries, ad valorem Rs. 4-11-0 per cent.

anchor.surface_text: Class V is headed Drugs, spices and gums, toilet requisites and perfumes, and item 44 reads Betel-nuts, gums, spices, Indian herbs and Indian raw medicines and drugs, such as nuts, ilaichi, laung, jaiphal, jaipatri, dalchini., sont, katha, zeera, Dhania garlic, dry chillies, pepper, shahzeera, maithi, sarso, etc. and known as kirana  groceries . Item 44 is chargeable ad valorem at Rs. 4-11-0 per cent.

facts.text: Item 17: Vegetable oils number hydrogenated number provided elsewhere such as ... Sarso Tel..., duty 4 annas per maund.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to these entries, there is item 17, which reads Vegetable oils  number hydrogenated  number provided elsewhere such as Tilli Tel, Sarso Tel, Alsi Tel, Falli Tel, Narial Tel, Andi Tel, which are chargeable to a duty of 4 annas per maund.

facts.text: Sarso is an oil seed, conceded on all hands.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded on all hands that sarso is an oil seed, and if there was numberhing more in the Schedule a duty of 2 annas per maund would be leviable on sarso as an oil seed.

facts.text: Dispute arises because sarso mentioned in Item 44 with higher duty.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute arises, because sarso is mentioned again in Item 44 with a very much higher duty,

facts.text: Appellant Committee contends words 'number specifically mentioned elsewhere' in item 4 exclude sarso, liable under item 44.

anchor.surface_text: and it is companytended by the appellant Committee that the words number specifically mentioned elsewhere in item 4 exclude sarso from that item, and that its specific mention in item 44 makes it liable to the higher duty indicated there.

facts.text: Sarso admitted sold as kirana and as a spice.

anchor.surface_text: Sarso, it is admitted, is sold as kirana and as a spice.

facts.text: Affidavit of respondents shows one maund sarso oil expressed from three maunds of oil seed.

anchor.surface_text: sarso oil  a maund of which, as the affidavit of the respondents shows, is expressed from three maunds of oil seed

facts.text: Price of sarso taken as Rs. 30 per maund as stated in affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: if the price of sarso is taken as Rs. 30 per maund as stated in the affidavit.

facts.text: Rules framed on June 4, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: appended to the Rules framed on June 4, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Class V deals with spices and groceries and the concluding words of item 44 known as kirana determine the ambit of that item. Though sarso might be mentioned there, it must be taken to have been mentioned as a spice or as kirana and not as oil seed. The extent of item 4, which deals with oil seeds of every description, could only be cut down by a specific mention elsewhere of an item as an oil seed.

concepts.interpretation: Specific mention of sarso in item 44 is limited by the class heading 'Drugs, spices and gums...' and concluding words 'known as kirana groceries'; interpreted as spice/kirana, not oil seed

concepts.interpretation: Exclusion from general entry 'oil-seeds of every description not specifically mentioned elsewhere' requires specific mention elsewhere as oil-seeds, not in different character

issues.text: Whether the imposition of ad valorem octroi duty at Rs. 4-11-0 percent on sarso oil seeds under item 44 as against other oil seeds under item 4 is ultra vires the Municipal Committee under Article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Nagpur later, of Madhya Pradesh against the appellants alleging inter alia that this imposition of octroi duty ad valorem at Rs. 4-11-0 percent on sarso oil seeds as against other oil seeds was ultra vires the Municipal Committee under Art. 14 of the Constitution. They also averred that octroi duty was properly leviable under item 4 and not under item 44. In the High Court,

issues.text: Whether octroi duty on sarso oil seeds is leviable under item 4 (oil-seeds of every description not specifically mentioned elsewhere) or under item 44?

anchor.surface_text: the words not specifically mentioned elsewhere in item 4 exclude sarso from that item, and that its specific mention in item 44 makes it liable to the higher duty indicated there. The learned single Judge of the High Court held in favour of the Municipality. According to him, this reason was sound and the higher duty demanded was the proper duty payable. The Divisional Bench on the other hand, points out that the two classes I and V are entirely different. Class 1 deals with articles of food or drink for use for men and animals while Class V deals with drugs, spices and gums, toilet requisites and perfumes. The division indicates clearly that goods belonging to one category are not included in the goods belonging to the other. The Divisional Bench also points out that item 4 must be read as it stood and the specific mention must be in the same manner in which that entry was framed.

issues.text: Whether the 'specific mention elsewhere' in item 4 requires the mention to be specifically as oil seeds and not in some other character?

anchor.surface_text: the words not specifically mentioned elsewhere in item 4 exclude sarso from that item, and that its specific mention in item 44 makes it liable to the higher duty indicated there. ... In our opinion, the Divisional Bench of the High Court was right when it said that the specific mention elsewhere must be as oil seeds and not as something else.

issues.text: Whether sarso mentioned in item 44 of Class V (Drugs, spices and gums...) is to be treated as an oil seed or as a spice or kirana grocery?

anchor.surface_text: Class V deals with spices and groceries and the concluding words of item 44 known as kirana determine the ambit of that item. Though sarso might be mentioned there, it must be taken to have been mentioned as a spice or as kirana and not as oil seed. The extent of item 4, which deals with oil seeds of every description, could only be cut down by a specific mention elsewhere of an item as an oil seed.

issues.text: Whether in case of doubt in interpretation of taxing provision, the doubt should be resolved in favour of the taxpayer?

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it may be said that if there be any doubt, the Divisional Bench of the High Court very properly resolved it in favour of the taxpayer.

The division indicates clearly that goods belonging to one category are not included in the goods belonging to the other.

arguments.claim: Specific mention elsewhere must be as oil seeds and not as something else

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Divisional Bench of the High Court was right when it said that the specific mention elsewhere must be as oil seeds and not as something else.

arguments.claim: Sarso in item 44 must be taken as mentioned as a spice or kirana grocery, not as oil seed, limited by class heading and concluding words 'known as kirana groceries'

anchor.surface_text: Class V deals with spices and groceries and the concluding words of item 44 known as kirana determine the ambit of that item. Though sarso might be mentioned there, it must be taken to have been mentioned as a spice or as kirana and not as oil seed.

arguments.claim: Extent of item 4 on oil seeds can only be cut down by specific mention elsewhere as an oil seed

anchor.surface_text: The extent of item 4, which deals with oil seeds of every description, could only be cut down by a specific mention elsewhere of an item as an oil seed.

arguments.claim: Each item in the long list of item 44 is referable to the class heading as drug, spice, gum etc.; sarso mentioned as spice, drug or herb sold as kirana

anchor.surface_text: Item 44 contains fairly long list, out of which we have quoted a few illustrative items. Each of these items is referable to the general heading either as a drug or a spice or gum, etc. Sarso, it is admitted, is sold as kirana and as a spice.

arguments.claim: Bye-law intention must be considered; if special tax on sarso as oil seed intended, it would have specific mention as oil seed with different duty, not hidden in kirana list

anchor.surface_text: The mention of sarso there is limited by the general heading to which it belongs, namely, a spice, drug or herb sold as kirana. No doubt, sarso as an oil seed is the same article as sarso sold as kirana but we must take into account the intention behind the bye-law and give effect to it.

arguments.claim: Absurd anomaly if item 44 applies: duty on extracted sarso oil is only 4 annas per maund but on three maunds of sarso seeds would be much higher

anchor.surface_text: One would not expect that it would be included in a long list of articles of kirana and in this indirect way be taken out from a very comprehensive entry like item 4, where oil seeds of every description are mentioned. Though the next argument is not conclusive because there is no logic behind a tax, still it is to be noted that sarso oil  a maund of which, as the affidavit of the respondents shows, is expressed from three maunds of oil seed  bears only an octroi duty of 4 annas per maund, while three maunds of sarso oil seed under item 44, if it were applicable, bear a duty of Rs. 4-3-6 per maund

arguments.claim: Any doubt in interpretation resolved in favour of the taxpayer

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it may be said that if there be any doubt, the Divisional Bench of the High Court very properly resolved it in favour of the taxpayer.

holdings.text: The specific mention elsewhere must be as oil seeds and not as something else.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Divisional Bench of the High Court was right when it said that the specific mention elsewhere must be as oil seeds and not as something else.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Item 4 covers oil-seeds of every description not specifically mentioned elsewhere; exclusion requires mention in same capacity as oil-seed, applying textual interpretation and agreeing with Divisional Bench.

holdings.text: Sarso mentioned in item 44 must be taken to have been mentioned as a spice or as kirana and not as oil seed.

anchor.surface_text: Class V deals with spices and groceries and the concluding words of item 44 known as kirana determine the ambit of that item. Though sarso might be mentioned there, it must be taken to have been mentioned as a spice or as kirana and not as oil seed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Class V heading 'Drugs, spices and gums...' and 'known as kirana groceries' limit sarso's mention via noscitur a sociis to spice/kirana context, not overriding item 4's oil-seed classification.

holdings.text: The extent of item 4, which deals with oil seeds of every description, could only be cut down by a specific mention elsewhere of an item as an oil seed.

anchor.surface_text: The extent of item 4, which deals with oil seeds of every descrip- tion, could only be cut down by a specific mention elsewhere of an item as an oil seed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General entry in item 4 not narrowed by mention in different category/character; requires same-description specificity for exception.

holdings.text: If there be any doubt, the Divisional Bench of the High Court very properly resolved it in favour of the taxpayer.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, it may be said that if there be any doubt, the Divisional Bench of the High Court very properly resolved it in favour of the taxpayer.
